text:
This is the best Spanish rice recipe on this site! I don't understand why people don't follow the direction to saute the rice! This is not supposed to be a "sticky rice" like Puerto Rican or Chinese rice, but that's what you'll get if you don't saute it first.  I don't agree that you should brown it.... it should turn translucent, but not brown.  If you are adding fresh garlic, add it after sauteing the rice and only cook it long enough for it to release it's aroma..don't brown it-it will turn bitter. After you add the liquid, bring the rice to a full, rolling boil before turning it down to low and putting the lid on. Also, make sure you have a tight fitting lid...cover it with foil to make it tighter if necessary.  Don't peek while the rice it cooking!  After 20 minutes move it off the heat and let it "rest" another 5 minutes. If you do these things you will have purfect rice! Even though I ususally use homemade salsa, I think the Pace "Make Mine Medium" gives the right amount of heat and flavor to the dish.  Thanks for a great recipe that everyone can  master and enjoy!

text:
HELPFUL TIPS NOT MENTIONED: I've tried all the other recipes on this site & decided this is the best!  I like using salsa more than diced tomatoes b/c it has more flavor and spice ...and it doesn't taste like you just dumped salsa in it like I expected.  This is only for my family of 4, so I use 3/4C of uncooked rice, definitely a little more than half a tablespoon of olive oil (full recipe calls for too much), with 3/4 of the can of chicken broth (approx 1 1/2C), BUT still use 1C of salsa as I feel it's necessary, as well as a few dashes of pepper.   I only brown rice a few minutes longer after it's turned WHITE (very apparent white color).  Being Asian myself, I could cook rice w/my eyes closed it seems.  lol  Many times we don't add onions b/c I'm too lazy to dice them.  If we do, it definitely needs more than suggested or it's pointless adding. It's even better when you add diced green & red peppers to the rice you are browning or use green onion instead of white/red.  We eat the rice every time we make "Whit's Chicken Enchiladas" which is SUPER EASY and YUMMY! This takes less time than indicated for the rice to be done.  Also great to put in baking dish, add cheese, and bake at 350 until it melts! :)

text:
I made this yesterday to go with the Mexican Theme of my son and husband's birthday party dinner. I modified it for a large group and used 6 cups chicken broth, 1 1/2 cups picante sauce and 4 cups rice. I did have to add about 2 cups more water since the rice was still a little chewy after cooking down.  I then just added garlic and onion powder to it, spread it in a 9x13 baking pan and sprinkled mexican blend cheese over the top and put in the oven for about 15 min till the cheese was melted.  this was sooo good and sooo easy to make! Thanks for the great recipe!

Either need to do that or cut rice from 1 & 1/2 C. down to 1 C.  Also, did not brown rice as read reviews saying made it too crunchy.  I sauteed onions and then added broth, rice, and salsa and cooked slowly so that rice would be soft.  A keeper!

text:
I have tried many Spanish rice recipes, only to be continually disappointed.  I was about ready to give up until I found this one!  I have made it so many times!  And, it heats up just as good for leftovers, a huge bonus!  The liquid to rice ratio is absolutely PERFECT, don't mess with it!  After lightly browning the rice, I add in the broth and salsa and sprinkle just a touch of salt.  I stir it very lightly, just to blend and then bring it to a boil.  Once it comes to a boil, turn the heat down to the LOWEST setting, cover and let cook for 15 minutes.  Remove from the burner and let sit for another 10 minutes before uncovering.  The rice turns out perfect EVERY time!  UPDATE 5/15/13 - I still make this recipe all the time!  Last time I made it, I only had beef broth handy so I used that in place of the chicken broth - then, feeling adventurous, I also added in 1 Tablespoon of taco seasoning and didn't add any salt... can I just say WOW!  It was amazing, you should try it!

This is a great dish! The first time I tried it, I followed the recipe exactly, and it turned out great! The second time, I wanted to use ingredients in "as they come" quantities. My chicken broth comes in cans aof 15.5 ounces, just shy of two cups. The salsa comes in a 16 ounce (by weight) container, and is over one cup. Wanting a more saucy rice, I used the smallest onion I had, 1 cup of rice instead of 1.5 cups, one can of broth, and one jar of salsa. I enjoyed it just as much.   What a wonderful recipe this cook submitted! It's so much better than anything I've used from a package, and gave me the courage to modify it just a bit to suit my needs!

text:
MUY DELICIOSO, I read some of the reviews and made a few changes because of them. PERFECTION! I used brown rice for its nutrients and reduced it to 1 1/4 cups, added a little more broth (2 1/4 cups) and also added  a tsp of cumin and cayenne pepper, salt & pepper to taste. It was delicious! VERY IMPORTANT TO NOT PEEK  DURING THE COOKING PROCESS. Since I used brown rice I added more cooking time -- 30 mins. Then I let it sit another 15 mins. before I took the lid off. Also, you really want to sauté the rice till it looks transparent before adding the liquids and that will ensure a fluffy result, not mushy. My family absolutely loved it and said it was restaurant quality! Definitely a keeper. Mahalo!

text:
This makes a fairly good rice, but plan accordingly if you use BROWN RICE. It WILL NOT be done in the time specified. I know brown & wild rices tend to take longer than white, but after 20 minutes, it was still fairly crunchy and swimming in broth/salsa. I've tried this twice now just to be sure I wasn't doing something else wrong. Be sure to allow about double the cook time if your family uses brown rice.

text:
I don't need to try any more Spanish rice or Mexican rice recipes: this one is the winner.  It was so delicious that I looked forward to eating the leftovers!  Do use the 2 Tbl of oil, as part of that is necessary for when you add the rice.  Also, use an entire small onion and go ahead and cook it until it starts to brown and caramelize.  Make sure to use long-grain or basmati rice.  We used vegetarian broth and everyone highly enjoyed this rice.  It's great as a tasty side with your home-made Mexican dinner (if you have not yet tried the recipe "Authentic Enchiladas Verdes" on allrecipes.com yet, you MUST TRY IT!!  We used Quorn chicken substitute) or you can put tasty beans over it or use it in a burrito.  The recipe is easy and simple and still surprisingly good.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is a really easy and good recipe and I really enjoyed it. But I do have to say that I read in a previous review that you will acheive "sticky rice" if you do not saute the rice. And I just have to say that this is not true. You do not have to saute the rice if you do not choose to, although it does add some nice flavor to the dish. The only way you will acheive "sticky rice" like what they use in many oriental dishes is if you use short grain rice. The reason is because molecularly speaking, it has a different amount of gluten than med or short grain rice and therefore the heat and steam begins to break down the sugars in short grain rice much more. That is what creates sticky rice, not the subtraction of sauteing it. So now we are left with this... To saute, or not saute. That is the question! Haha!

text:
I have tried several spanish rice recipes from this site and this one is by far the best! I did not follow other reviews and feel that the measurements are just right.  My rice was not mushy and was not sticking to the pan/pot!  I used 1 can of Rotel diced tomatoes with green chilies since I did not have salsa.  I did add some chili powder and ground cumin to the rice (just lightly sprinkled over the rice).  As other reviews stated, you absolutely must saute the rice first (not brown, the rice should be translucent).  Thanks for the perfect recipe! UPDATE 4/19/2016: I've been making this for a while, but tonight I added about 1/2 cup La Preferida tomato sauce instead of chunky salsa and felt the use of tomato sauce was much better. Here's what I do whenever making spanish rice now: 1) saute 1.5 cups white rice (jasmine), 2) stir in the diced onion and 1 small clove garlic, minced, 3) stir in salsa/tomato sauce, 4) Add 2 cups water or chicken broth, 5) Stir in  about 1 tsp cumin and 1 tsp oregano (you could also add in paprika or chili powder--1 tsp should be ok), 5) Reduce heat to low, 6) cover skillet with aluminum foil and then put on the lid. Do not open lid/foil. Just leave it alone for 20 minutes, then check to make sure it's done--it will be done in 20 minutes! Remove from heat. You can leave it covered while finishing other dishes you might be making to keep the rice warm and moist. Delicious! Follow the recipe as stated or with my notes and you will NOT have under

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm sorry, but I don't know how this recipe gets such a high rating. I had a bad feeling it wouldn't turn out, and it didn't. You know why? Because there is too much rice for the amount of liquid. 1 1/2 cups of rice requires 3 cups of liquid. 2 cups of stock + 1 cup of *chunky* salsa does not equal 3 cups of liquid. The rice absorbed all the liquid in the pot and was still hard, so I had to add more water and cook longer. BTW, I actually used picante sauce, which is quite a bit more watery than chunky salsa, so I can only imagine how hard the rice would have been if I had used salsa.  In order for this to turn out you either need to use less rice or more liquid.  FWIW, the flavor was OK (a little bland, but that's easy to fix) but the texture (hardness) wasn't.
Review:

5

text:
I really liked this dish.  I added 2 tablespoons of red bell pepper at the same time as the onion.  After the 5 minutes, i added 2 cloves of garlic and waited 1 min.  I added the chicken broth and fresh salsa, brought the whole thing to a rolling boil, then reduced the heat to low and covered for 20 mins.  After the 20 minutes, i took the rice off the heat (still covered) and let it sit another 5 min.  Right before serving I added about 1 tbsp of fresh parsely.

I served this rice with the "camarones al ajillo (garlic shrimp)" from this website.

text:
I've made this recipe twice:  once exactly as directed, and the second time adding 1 tablespoon chili powder and 1 teaspoon cumin.  The second time was definitely better for our Tex-Mex taste buds (although it did have kick).  I also used medium-hot chunky salsa, which added to the spicy flavor.  We loved it.  Having a Mexican restaurant on nearly every corner here in Texas, we've become quite the Spanish rice lovers, and this fit the bill for a version to make at home.  But, it did need a little extra zip for our Texas taste.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sautéed about 1/4 C. minced onion, 3 green onions and 1 hefty garlic clove then added the rice to sautee. Used 1 can of mild Rotel (15 oz.) and 2 C. chicken stock with 1.5 cups of white Jasmine rice, cooking 22 minutes then allowing to set for 5 with the lid on. The end result was fluffy instead of gummy and very flavorful. Next time I'll add 1/2 tsp. cumin and maybe a dash of chili powder, but the overall flavor was great and, importantly, the texture was SO MUCH BETTER than any packaged rice of ANY brand (and believe me, we've tried them all).  I served this to 4 adults with some leftovers -- not a ton.  I'd 1.5 the recipe if serving for 6.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was making my Chicken Enchiladas for dinner and need a quick side dish. Figured this recipe looked easy and had lots of good reviews. Luckily I had all the ingredients on hand.
After reading some of the reviews I made a few changes as others found helpful. First while softening up the onions I added in a little garlic. I did not brown the rice, just sauted it before it started to color up. I was using a long grain rice so I added in an extra 1/2 cup of broth and also a couple tablespoons green chillies since I had some left over from my enchilada recipe. I sealed the pan with foil and the lid and did not peak until the 20 minutes was up.
Came out nice and fluffy, a little brown on the bottom, but it had a nice flavor and happy it wasn't all clumpy.

Yummy and EASY.  I do add some garlic while the oil is heating int the skillet.  I use olive oil as it's a little more aromatic.  We searched and searched for a good home-made spanish rice recipe and this is IT.  It's not too sticky like some.  Also, if I want it to be a little fluffier, I bake it in a 350 oven with a lid on the pan for about 45 minutes...while I bake chicken.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/12652.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not the best spanish rice I've ever had, but it's so easy and tasty that I plan on making it often.  The first time I made it, I fried the rice and it came out a little chewy.  The second time, I skipped the frying and it came out great.  I've used beef broth instead of chicken broth, and liked that a little better.
Also--this is key--the better the salsa, the better the rice will turn out.  I've made it with regular salsa in a jar and it turned out so-so, but when I made it with the fresh kind you get in the gourmet-deli section of the grocery store it was really good!

userID:
2223580
Display Name:
sheila
isPro:

5

103

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/917697.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Beeeeyooootiful Spanish Rice - so easy. Please, remember to season for your tastes! If you like heat, add it! if you like it extra tomato-ey add it! Other wonderful things that you can add or not to your taste --- olives! more garlic, diced peppers, hot sauce, kidney beans, chick peas, white beans. But the single most important step in this rice dish is you MUST sauté it first. the second - DONT use minute rice.
third - remember, everyone's stove is a bit different, every cup of rice is a bit different.. the standard liquid to rice measure is two to one. meaning two of liquid, one of rice - this recipe allows for 1 and half cups rice, so you would need 3 cups liquid for it to work, 2 of chicken broth and the other cup from the chunky salsa - not all salsa's are the same so in short keep your eye on the liquid. Espcially if you are adding additional ingredients that have a lot of liquid like diced tomatoes....last - you bring this to a boil, and then you slow simmer.  I generally bring mine to a boil, let it boil a good 4-5 minutes and I turn my stove top OFF(electric stove). I let it sit tightly covered for 20 mins on the same burner. but that's me and my stove - think about how your rice works on your stove - and if you have to have your stove on, then leave it on low but very low so the bottom doesn't stick or burn.. (I usually add a spray of butter flavored Pam to the bottom of my pot before putting anything, even water in. Thanks for the EASY and great tasting recipe!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been dying to find a perfect Spanish rice recipe, and as far as I'm concerned this is it. I used 3/4 cup rice, 2/3 cup salsa, and a cup of water, and it came out perfect. The amount of onion this calls for is questionable because it's so small, so instead of chopped onion I subbed in some onion powder. I also threw in a little sofrito (maybe a couple tablespoons). Everyone loved it, and I imagine the addition of some jalapenos would please those who need a little kick.

Update: I tend to cook this as a sticky rice without frying the rice first, and my wife cooks it as per directions. Both ways taste great. I've found not frying the rice takes about 20 minutes on my stove, and frying takes 25 (with 5-10 minutes of rest time after it's finished cooking). It doesn't hurt to throw in some chili peppers, sazon, or sofrito either!

text:
I don't get this at all.. For one, the cooking times are COMPLETELY off. I can't fault this recipe 100% for that tho.... I subbed brown rice for white and think this may have been the reason my rice wasn't cooked thru after 20 minutes (but then again, many reviews specifically mention having to cook for longer than stated, even when using white rice as directed). Unfortunately, I'm not going to try this again to find out! To be fair, I'll award three stars just *in case* my substitution is totally to blame. My main gripe with this is two-fold. First, the "suggested" cooking time for sauteeing the onion is WAY off (my gosh)! I have been cooking for years and know that cooking onions over MEDIUM heat for 5 MINUTES is far too long! It should take a couple of minutes MAX (a few if you cook on low heat) to soften such a SMALL amount of onion. Second, you should ALWAYS bring your rice / liquid to a boil FIRST, then cover and simmer until done (duh). I'm not sure why the recipe submitter didn't instruct to do this (?). I'm very puzzled.... This seems to have been a hit for so many people. I'm a firm believer that if a recipe needs this much tweaking, it doesn't qualify as a "kitchen approved" recipe in the least (sorry!). Thanks anyways, ilovetocook.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/121107.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have always used a wonderful easy spanish rice recipe I was taught how to make from a mexican lady who makes it for her family.  I love the little clove of garlic, finely sliced carrot and corn, she adds to her Spanish Rice.  I also added a little more diced onion, to this recipe.  She also fries her rice before mixing anything with it.  Just till you see it start to brown or becomes translucent.  I didn't have the thick picante sauce so I used the mild regular.
If you don't have picante, just add some chicken broth, tomato sauce, garlic all into a blender and add it to your water and chicken broth to bring the liquid to the right measure for the spanish rice.  That's how my friend does her SRice adding the sliced carrot and corn.  Simple but very delicious.
Cover and don't peak as suggested in another post.  The rice cooked perfectly.

text:
I followed the recipe. Plus I've made rice before this way, i.e. sauteing it first and then adding broth to finish cooking it, but this recipe did not work. I think the problem was that 1 1/2 cups rice was too much. It never got translucent and then took forever to brown. Although browned, it was hard and uncooked, as expected. However, adding the broth and cooking for 20 minutes did not help. I kept adding broth, and then water. This rice took an hour to cook. It kept sticking and burning to the bottom of the pan. If there is a certain type of rice kernel that should be used, it should be specified. I used a white rice I had on hand - I think it was pearl rice - and it was a disaster. Fought with it, as I say, for an hour. It tasted alright when finished, but much of that had to do with the good, fresh salsa I used. Will not try this recipe again.

This recipe is awesome...even better than our best Mexican restaurant here in Terre Haute, IN.  I did make a few changes.  I used 2 tbsp butter instead of oil, and I used a quarter onion instead of measuring out 2 tbsp.  Also, I didn't really wait for the rice to brown, just until a little translucent (something like 1 minutes).  After adding the water, bullion, and salsa, I cooked a few minutes until it started boiling before covering for 20 minutes on low.  Regardless, this was "¡Muy bien!"

text:
Pretty mushy. Nothing like actual spanish rice. Super bland as well. I suggest getting the white rice in the hispanic section at your local grocery store. Jasmine rice just doesn't cut it. Also, you need way more than 2 tbs of onion. I added cumin, chili powder, garlic, serrano peppers and corn. Without these things it would have tasted like nothing. I don't know why people are so stoked on this recipe.

text:
I think the recipe was great!  For the few that didn't get the rice to cook properly I would suggest that you cover the rice while cooking and Do Not lift the lid until the end of the cooking time.  Rice steams to cook and apparently someone either didn't cover it or kept lifting the lid during the steaming process.

text:
This recipe is really really good!  You do have to follow the directions exactly, though.  Thanks to Karen H for the tip about the foil, that really helped out.  (Covering the pan with foil and then putting the lid on for a tight seal.)  You have to remember that the salsa is going to make all the difference in this recipe.  Use a salsa that you know you like, and one that is not too hot for whoever you are feeding.  Also, the amount of liquid in the salsa needs to be considered, too.  I can't remember what salsa I used, but it came out perfectly!  Good luck, it's the best!!

text:
Previous reviewer must have made this wrong.  This is delicious.  Add more chicken broth if needed as rice tends to soak up the liquid if it sets for a long period of time.  Also, use a good brand of picante sauce for best results. This is definitely better than restaurant rice!

text:
I read the reviews, and also made the following changes. Increased onion (1/2 of an onion - chopped), and chicken stock to 3 cups (white rice is usually cooked 2-1 ratio liquid to rice). After the rice was browned, I added a little adobo, and put all ingredients in a glass covered dish, and into the microwave for 25 minutes. No stirring, no peeking. Perfect. Would make this again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/110619.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy, with results as good as recipes that have 6+ ingredients.  The real deciding factor in this recipe is which salsa you use.  I use only high-quality, organic salsa with plenty of cilantro and the flavor is wonderful.  If you use cheap, crappy, generic picante sauce, you will get a bland and too-dry version.  Picante sauce has a much lower moisture content than salsa.  The only thing I add to this recipe is to throw in a little roasted corn when I have it.  And remember, SAUTE THE RICE FIRST, PEOPLE.  It makes a huge difference.

text:
This was by far the simplest - tastiest - super easy Spanish rice on the planet! I have tried time and time again and they were too salty, scorched on the bottom, no Spanish flavor. I could go on but will save you the boredom. THIS one is easy and did NOT scorch. I did use my Dutch oven on the stove top and stirred quite a bit. *** I added more onion than called for just because I don't want my husband near me and food at the same time (j/k) I ? Onion. I used an authentic quality chunky flavorful salsa - Pass on the Pace - And a Must Must Must - ADD CUMIN! Cumin is a basic Mexican spice that you will thank me for later. Also. It's awesome the next day.

text:
So, I used mild picante instead of salsa (because that's all I had), and EVOO and brown rice because that's all we use.  I had to keep adding water and the recipe took WAAAAAAAAAY longer than directions indicated. -of course, I anticipated it to take a little longer because of the difference in rice, but this was exceptionally longer - like over twice as long.  The flavor was ~ok.  I was excited to switch up our usual plain 'ole rice with our fajitas, and it worked out great, really!  I am interested to see how chunky salsa changes the flavor.  Overall, I LOVE how heart healthy and NATURAL this recipe is.  MUCH better than any store bought package and relatively easy to make.

text:
Made this for guests as a side to chicken enchiladas. Made with brown rice instead of white because it was what I had. Otherwise followed the recipe exactly. So delicious and so easy! Also made spanish beans with the same basic recipe. Oil, onions, 2 cans of beans (1 black, 1 pink), 1/2 cup salsa, cooked down a little of the liquid, then left in fridge all day to absorb flavor. Got lots of compliments on both. Delicious and inexpensive sides. Beware this makes a LOT of rice. Recipe served 4 people with tons left over. Highly recommended!

text:
Thought this was really and surprisingly authentic.  
 
Made some changes  . . . had to increase and adjust the recipe b/c I cut up about a generous half cup each of green and red pepper and onion.  It would have overpowered the 1.5 cups of rice.  Okay, I sauteed the 3 vegetable ingredients in a little olive oil and seasoned w/ little salt and pepper and dash of cumin and chili powder(s).  Once softened and fragrant, I added the (extra) rice, chicken broth and salsa in the order per the recipe.   Once done, I mixed and served with freshly and finely chopped cilantro.  The addition of the cilantro added a huge taste element, in my opinion.  Would make this again, I may try and add a little garlic with the sauteed vegetable mixture though.

text:
followed basic recipe, just added  2 cloves of minced garlic after rice was browning, some chili powder, added some cumin, and a little bit of crushed red pepper - no rules set in stone so feel free to experiment, thats why they have cook offs. I used powerded chicken flavoring and I doubt it would be any better if you used homemade - no need to add any xtra salt as processed powders have plenty of it already. I used a generic mild salsa from walmart. Great side dish and very easy to make just make sure to stir often when browning rice and final simmer. I'm not a real heath nut but I've been using plain yogurt insted of sour cream (U won't be able to tell the diff) as a topping, after a generious amount of cheese melted over a tamale or burrito with shreeded lettuce has been applied first - don't forget the refried beans of course!

text:
Without the salsa this is your basic fried rice recipe, which is very good by itself.  With the salsa added it is spectacular.  I have never had Spanish Rise this good in a restaurant.  I doubled the oil (olive oil), used 1/2 cup of chopped onions and only 1 cup of rice.  Just be sure to check the rice, at about 15 minutes, that is isn't burning on the bottom.  It may look moist and fine on top, but dried out on the bottom.  Can't wait to pair this with our homemade refried beans and tacos!

text:
Made this tonight, it's after midnight that I'm posting this though.  Anyway, made it Oct. 22nd and I must say, it turned out awesome.  A couple of things, for the liquid, I added 2 2/3 cups of chicken broth. I already knew there was not enough liquid just by reading the recipe.  I added about 1/2 cup of chopped onion, which I sauteed in butter with the rice.  So yes, I did them together, not separate.  ***Note: I did "not" use picante sauce.  Instead, I added about 1 1/2 cups of mild chunky salsa.  Hubby tried it and fell in love with it.  He said I can make this for him anytime.  It cooked up perfectly with a nice flavor.  Will definitely use again.

I made this because of all the rave reviews, but I think it lacked a LOT of flavor.  I did add one extra Cup of broth per other reviewers suggestions of not enough liquid. Sorry for the mediocre review, but it just was not the best Spanish rice I have had.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I must have "browned" the rice too long because a) I had to cook the rice way longer than 20 minutes and b) I still ended up with grains that were crunchy.  Other than that, I really enjoyed the flavor of the dish.  As others mentioned, I had to add an additional 1/2 cup of water after the 20 minutes, as there was not enough liquid left to keep cooking the rice the additional time it needed.  I added some cooked shredded chicken at the end and made a meal of it.  I will make this again, but I will not "brown" the rice at all.  Also, this may have made a difference in how much I liked this: I added a bit of cayenne and cumin at the end - it added the perfect amount of zip.  I give three stars because of the directions to brown the rice and the not-enough-liquid.

I just made this recipe following the directions and it turned out great!  I did bring the chicken broth, salsa, onion, and rice to a boil before covering, reducing heat to simmer for 20 minutes though.  I think the originator of the recipe just left that part out, but meant well.  If you have cooked rice, then you know to do this. This recipe would also be good with some browned/drained ground beef with it..that's how my mom always makes it with the ground beef added.

userID:

Display Name:
BLIZLADY

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It turns out pretty much perfect every time. I may or may not have to add a little more liquid to the rice after the 20 minutes, but make sure you saute the rice until it is clear, after adding the liquid and other ingredients bring the pan to a boil, then turn the heat down to low (just enough to keep a simmer) and cover.  Don't remove the lid to check.  After 20 minutes, remove from heat and let stand about 5-10 minutes longer.  I have pans with glass lids so I can see how much liquid is left.    This is not much different than the directions on how to make rice-a-roni and I never had problems with it.  Don't keep it on high heat or the liquid will boil out too quickly and the rice won't have a chance to cook properly.
Review:

I've been looking for a good Spanish Rice recipe for quite some time and I think I have finally found the one for me!  I try to avoid boxed/processed foods whenever I can but that often means a time consuming, labor intensive alternative when made from scratch.  This recipe produced a moist, flavorful, slightly spicy rice that was delicious!  I used a medium heat jarred salsa and the rest were fresh ingredients so I know it did not have any preservatives or unhealthy additives.  Plus it was just as easy, if not easier to prepare as the boxed variety.  This one goes into my binder of Family Favorite Recipes!!!!

This rice has outstanding flavor and texture. I use brown basmati rice and add about 1/2 tsp. cumin and 1/2 tsp. chili powder. As previously mentioned, make sure to brown the rice first.   This recipe is easily doubled, and is a great choice for a do-ahead side dish...it tastes as good, if not better, rewarmed!

text:
I made this to use as filling for meatless stuffed peppers (I usually use a box mix but wanted something without all the additives) but we devoured it before I had a chance to prep the peppers! YUM!  

Slight modifications:  Used just 1 TBLSPN Olive Oil to cut down on calories, 4 TBSPNS of Onion (we like onion!) and a clove of minced garlic.  I used a Southwest style salsa I had on hand so the black beans and corn in it was a nice addition. Also used veggie broth instead of chicken and added a few shakes of chili powder & cumin.  

Thanks for the recipe, I plan on making my own spanish rice from now on!

It takes closer to an hour so be patient.

I'm so pleased with this recipe I couldn't wait to post a review! I was looking for something quick and easy and this just seemed too easy to actually be good, but boy was I wrong!  I made it tonight and it tasted wonderful and I got rave reviews.  I followed the ingredients exactly, but after slightly browning the rice with the onions, I threw that into the rice cooker, along with the broth and salsa (used Taco Bell Chunky Medium Salsa), and let it do it's thing. text:
This dish was good the first night I served it.  However, the leftovers the second day were exceptional. I did add more tomatoes to the leftovers but I credit the marinading of the flavors for the improved taste. With a few extra canned tomatoes, this dish is a great source of lycopene and it is especially healthy if you use brown rice and olive oil. Karen H's recommendations were on the money -- don't over sauté the rice or the garlic and you will end up with a tasty rice side dish.  Thanks Angie.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I spent YEARS looking for the right Spanish rice recipe.  This is it!

The key is finding the right salsa - it makes all the difference. (Even if I like the salsa on it's own, sometimes it doesn't work well in this recipe) It's worth trying multiple brand to find the right one.

Also, get your chicken broth boiling before you put it in the rice - it gives it the perfect Mexican restaurant texture! (I microwave it in a measuring cup - but be careful of the steam as you pour it in the skillet)

text:
Really great recipe. I quartered a full Spanish onion instead of chopped or diced, I added a clove of garlic after adding the broth, and after the rice was done, I cut up two cooked chicken breasts into strips and laid them on top of the rice, covered it with a mixture of shredded mild cheddar, white cheddar, and Havarti, then threw the skillet into 350 degree oven until cheese melted. I added cilantro before serving and also topped with sliced avocado. Yum!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
loved it! easy and delicious - FINALLY i can make something that tastes like the spanish rice when we go out to eat!
i've made this according to directions, several times, here are my observations:
1. no need to start the onion first.  just add it with the rice in the beginning.  sautee them both together for about 10 minutes, until the rice is well coated and browning.
2. sauteing the rice definitely makes a difference! i forgot to do it once, and was disappointed with the stickiness of that batch.
3. changing the salsa completely changes the flavor! our favorite is pace picante sauce (medium).

text:
This recipe is fantastic as is which is why I gave it five stars.  What I also love about this recipe is that it is very versatile. I will sometimes throw in a few add-ins such as corn, black beans, and diced cooked meat. I've also added Chipotle powder, garlic powder, and a little splash of liquid smoke. It also works well with minute rice (be sure to reduce the amount of liquid by half a cup or more and it cooks much faster, so watch that).  Thank you for posting this wonderful recipe. It is a regularly requested dish in my home.

I was really prepared not to like this.....living in New Mexico and all.  But it was really, really good.  Had to add more chicken broth as I went, and I started with 2.5 cups, not the recommended 2.  But we are at a mile high elevation, so sometimes that is expected.  I used Pace Picante Medium sauce.  Also, added chopped green pepper with the onion, and more onion.  2 Tbsp., like some other reviewers said, is hardly worth it.  Half a chopped onion, half a chopped green pepper. Otherwise, followed the recipe, including the browning of the rice. This is Mexican restaurant worthy.

text:
This Spanish rice was delicious! I must admit that I had to modify it to use some tomatoes from my garden. I replaced the salsa with 2cups of cooked tomatoes  and McCormick's Mexican seasoning, and garlic. I used 1 cup of beef broth and 1 cup of long grain rice. I used  green pepper instead of onion. I made it a meal by add,ing browned lean ground beef and simmering it all for 20 minutes. I let it with the lid on for another 5 minutes ..... My husband loved it !

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This worked well for me as a starting point.  To make it for those of us who don't each chicken, I used a vegetable soup starter in water, pre-mixed before adding to the dish.  I also reduced the amount of rice (and water proportionally).

To make a complete meal in the one pan, I added medium-thinly-cut (1/4" - 1/2") tuna steaks to the pan when it began to simmer.  When the rice was done, so was the tuna.  Use fresh tuna fillets; not canned tuna!

BTW, I added garlic but I doubt I would have tasted the difference given the salsa's flavor dominated.

This is a great recipe given it's simplicity. I'm a compulsive modifier though, so I added a couple of garlic cloves when sautéing the onions. text:
Since finding this gem of a recipe, I have made it numerous times and never tire of it. As I don't care for spicy foods, I use mild salsa when making for myself. If friends are coming over and they like spicy, I use hot salsa for them and make another batch for myself with mild. To make a very quick meal, I slice Oscar Meyer turkey sausage, which is fully cooked, and add to the rice. Add a salad and crusty bread and voila, dinner in a jiffy. You cannot go wrong with this recipe.

This is the best Spanish rice.  I have been making only this now for the past year.  No more boxed mixes for us.  You can vary the salsa to your tastes.  I've tried many different types and it always turns out.  You don't have to use chicken broth. text:
This rice was amazing! I've always eaten Spanish rice but never really cared for it. I raved over this one, and I am my biggest critic. The kids even liked it. I browned the rice in butter. It still ended up very soft, not hard as others claimed and I truly cooked mine to a med golden brown. I used fresh garlic and because I had homegrown tomatoes and a green pepper, used that on top of the required amount of salsa. I agree that pepper is also needed. I was very skeptical about this tasting like jar salsa mixed with rice, but the chicken broth adds a unique, wonderful flavor and you would never know how simple this recipe actually is. I have found my keeper recipe!

This was a great recipe, but there was one very important step missing.  You should let the liquids come to a boil once you add the salsa and broth, and then cover and simmer.  I think this may be why a lot of people had hard rice.  I also added a can of diced tomatoes and green chiles and less salsa.  It came out perfectly!

This really was very tasty and couldnt be easier. Great basic recipe, I appreciate all the reviews and great rating, Im sure the recipe is fine as is but altered it to my taste, I like flavor! I forgot to rinse the rice so it was a "bit" more sticky than I like but I will definitely make this recipe again.

text:
I've made this twice now. The first time I followed it as written and it turned out fine. The second time I made it, I added about 1/2 cup of the onion and a dash of cumin. Just before serving I added about 3 tbsp of chopped green onions (just the green part) and gave it a quick stir. My fussy kids liked it better the second time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed recipe with more onion and some red bell pepper and Garlic.  Added a little bit more liquid.  Brought to full rolling boil before turning down to simmer.  Tasted it.  It was Ok, but not very authentic tasting.  Added Chili powder and cumin, put it over the top.  Was great, but I feel cumin and chili powder are vital to making this dish work.  Used medium picante, which was to spicy for my son.  If your not a fan of spicy, would rec. mild salsa/picante.  I think mild salsa would have been closer to authentic, but I liked the spice.  This is my first time making spanish rice.  I feel with the additions that I made it is a thousand times better than those bags you buy at the store! Great, easy base recipe!

text:
This is my go to Spanish Rice recipe! I always add a little more onions then the recipe calls for, just because we like onions in my house. Also, I don't cook the onion first.... I throw them in at the same time I'm browning the rice. The first few times I made this recipe I did it with cooking the onions first, but by the time the rice was done browning the onions would be burnt. Otherwise the recipe is perfect as is!

text:
I wasn't sure if I'd like this recipe as I've made a rice from this site before that called for adding salsa and didn't care for it.  Having used the exact same salsa in this recipe as I did then, I have discovered I LOVE this recipe!!  I did halve the recipe on everything with the exception of the onion--I used 1/4 cup, as I couldnt see saving a small portion of an already small onion.  This will be my go to recipe for spanish rice for now on.  No need to use store bought rices that are too high in sodium content anymore!!  I may try adding corn and black beans to it next time.  Thank you for sharing the recipe!!

text:
This was an excellent quick Spanish Rice dish to make just as written. I rated it on the cooks original recipe.  The second time I made it I added 1 whole chopped small Walla Walla onion instead of just 2 tablespoons plus also added one whole large minced fresh garlic clove to suit our particular taste.  Also seemed to need to add a little extra chicken broth towards the end of cooking because the rice wasn't quite tender and it was getting too dry (could have been the variety of rice I was using).  This recipe will get made whenever I make my husband Mexican recipes that need a rice side.  Thank you for sharing.

I made this just as written with one addition, I added a half of a hot banana pepper in with the onion.  I used home canned salsa and it was so good!  I made chicken breasts in the oven while this was on the stove top. text:
Taste was excellent, however in the end it needed more liquid.  The standard formula for rice is 2 cups water/liquid to 1 cup of rice.  This recipe only calls for 2 cups of broth.  There is a little liquid from the salsa, but not enough to make up the difference.  Next time I will use 3 cups of broth.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe. I have made this recipe several times now. I just wanted to tell others who have tried this what I believe to be a great tip. I use Uncle Ben's Rice. If you use Uncle Ben's Rice; The recipe is as follows. 1 and 1/2 cups of rice, one 14.5 oz. can of chicken broth and one 16 oz. jar of Pace Picante sauce. Follow the directions for cooking the rice on the box, which is bring to a boil, reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes. I would also suggest, stirring occassionally while it is simmering as the mixture does tend to stick. If you want to make more, just double the recipe. 3 cups rice, 2 cans broth, 2 sixteen oz. jars of Pace picante sauce. I've had great results using these measurements. Thank you so much for sharing this recipe. I Love spanish Rice.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2201089.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! So similar to my great-grandmother's authentic spanish rice.  My variation to make it closer to my grandmother's recipe include:
2 T olive oil
2 T Chopped onion
1.5 C uncooked white rice
2 C chicken broth (or regular water with lots of salt)
1 C diced tomatoes (or you can add a little extra)
1-2 garlic cloves lightly brown at the end with the rice and let it cook with the rice and water. Pull out at end of cooking.

None
text:
Hey I just made spanish rice yesterday!! This really is a more authentic Mexican spanish rice!! Some of the recipes that call for ground beef? Yeah...don't know where that comes from. My family and I usually use tomatoe sauce not salsa but hey, if you want something a little different....Make sure you use extra long grain rice not medium grain as it will be too mushy if you don't. If you don't have chicken broth on hand use water and season with garlic and onion powder salt and pepper comes out just as good. You're gonna need more liquid, usually 2 cups of liquid for every 1 cup of uncooked rice. So you should use 3 cups of chick. broth not 2 1/2. When rice starts to boil then reduce heat to low and cover. Perfect every time!!

text:
This was great!  I used 3/4 c rice, added enough chicken broth to the juice from a can of Rotel to equal 1 1/2 cups and threw in the tomatoes in place of the salsa called for in the recipe (salsa is highly coveted in my pantry since I rarely find my preferred brand on sale).  I cooked until the liquid had been absorbed by the rice.  This rice had wonderful flavor and will replace "Mexican Rice 1" as my go-to Mexican side dish.

text:
This was a great addition to burritos.  I increased the onion to about 1/3 c., but next time I would use a whole onion.  I also added about 1 cup fresh cilantro which I chopped and added after the rice had cooked about 20 minutes; I then let the rice sit for another 10-15 minutes before serving.  This recipe needed extra liquid to cook properly.  I thought this might be too salty with the broth and salsa, but it turned out just right.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy.  I love the addition of the salsa, it makes all the difference.  I did do something a little different, given I had to improvise.  Basically I mixed two recipes together, this one and salsa chicken. The chicken breasts I had were too small and misshapen lol so I cut them up, added salt, pepper and olive oil, baked and added it to this recipe (and kept this recipe as is).  I also added 1/2 tsp of taco seasoning and 1/4 tsp garlic powder. It was fantastic!  This way it would also be a fantastic filling for burritos, adding sour cream, cheese and refried beans...mmm.  I think I'll do that next time.  As is though I think this is a great side dish, something you can definitely see at a taqueria but I think I'll keep it with the few additions I made, it was just too good to change it!

I agree with the name of this recipe. It is by far the best Spanish Rice recipe that I have tried. I did not have chicken broth, so I just substituted water and chicken bullion. This is fantastic! text:
Yum! I did tweek this alittle but after making it yesterday, I made a second batch just because it was so good. I used jasmine rice. The longer grain brings out more flavor in my opinion. My major change was mostly due to personal preference. In the recipe - just says "Oil" so I used 1 tbsp of seasame oil and 2 tbsp of peanut oil..and 1/2 cup of onions because I love onions.  I used mild fire-roasted salsa, likely should have gone for medium. Low sodium chicken broth too. perfect!

text:
I made this rice tonight to go with my meatloaf. I followed Karen H's specific instructions cuz mine almost always comes out gummy and sticky. I am married to a Mexican Man and I know that the rice is supposed to be fried. I think, in the past, I have fried it too much. Please follow karen's instructions and your rice will come out just like it is supposed to nice and fluffy. I will add one thing, after it is done cooking, and sat for the 5 mins, fluff with a fork instead of stirring with a spoon. Very important! I got Rave reviews from the hubby for this rice tonight. It tasted delishious! I will do it this way from now on! Thank You ilovetocook.

I would give this a 4.5 if I could...not THE best but still VERY good!  It was a good, easy recipe for a side dish.  I have made another spanish rice recipe on this site which also called for browning the rice and it did not turn out very well...a little crunchy and a little chewy.  So on this recipe I decided to not brown the rice, which I highly recommend!.  I also added a little more onion since I like it and also thought the recipe needed some salt.  I also used a 'restaurant style' salsa since hubby doesn't like 'em chunky.  This was really good, next time I might turn it into a main dish and add some ground beef or even chicken!  Thank You!!

I gave this one five stars. I have made it 3 or 4 times and it is really good. One of the important parts is to brown the rice. I noticed some people skip it and it doesn't come out as good. I also discovered that adding some more salsa to it when you reheat it in the microwave works really great. This also goes for reheating left over restaraunt spanish rice.  I wouldn't change a thing about this recipe.

text:
Browning the rice first made this dish really amazing. I will be using that method for other recipes as well.

We forewent sauteing the onion with the recipe as we were already using large slices with our fajitas. We also added a couple tablespoons finely-chopped cilantro to the dish while it was cooking. It ended up being the best Spanish Rice recipe we've had.

Heavy skillet = cast iron pan. Always. Great, simple recipe, and really tasty. Cheers!

text:
I only had a half cup of salsa on hand so added an additional 1/2 cup of rotes.  Also used more onions than called for and added about half of a smaller bell pepper, diced.  I also added a bit of fresh garlic as well as salt and pepper.  This dish turned out great!  The additions to the recipe ensured that it was quite spicy.  If you are from south Louisiana as we are then it’s no problem for you however it may be too spicy for some folks!

I followed the recipe and it was perfect! My picky eaters love this and it has become my go-to for rice. The one thing I would add is NOT to sautee the onions first. Picante is a bit vinegar-ish.

text:
I never realized how easy Mexican rice was to make! Thank-you for posting a non-intimidating quick recipe for all of us to try out. This tastes good as is so don’t feel like you have to add anything but since it’s such a great baseline- it quickly gave me confidence to expand my creativity and try some stuff out:) I like adding Rotel vs. salsa for a more spicy version a long with some taco seasoning. I also add a bit more onion with some fresh red bell pepper too. Top it off when serving with some fresh cilantro and *voila* looks so pretty and tastes great. I serve it with stuffed chicken breast and served it to some guests and they all loved it. Thanks soooooo much for making me look so great, lol

userID:
25351538
Display Name:
Lele
isPro:
False
followersCount:

1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family likes this recipe it is easy one skillet meal. I do add a can of drained black beans, frozen cooked diced chicken breast or you can use uncooked chicken breast if frozen cut back on chicken broth a little bit bc water from frozen chkn adds liquid. After cooking the 20min. I topped it with chedder cheese and let melt. My kids like it as is
or served with tortilla chips /soft taco shells.  Sour cream & guacamole and the salsa left . Makes a great side.
I have added corn if I have left over corn from a previous dinner.  Fyi, if using raw chicken be sure that it gets done to safe temp.  I have continued cooking in the preheated oven at 350o for 15-20min if i used frozen whole chicken breast that were thick. The last few min in oven i added salsa & cheese on top.  Remember to use a oven safe skillet w/lid if using frozen whole breast it may need to finish up in oven will keep the bottom from burning or drying out the rice while the chicken cooks to safe temp. if your using raw diced chicken it is usually will be done on stovetop after the 20/25min. If using raw chicken try to put it in the boiling chicken broth at beginning of the recipe and boil a couple minutes before continuing  the recipe if its not huge/thick peices going in the oven may not be necessary.  I have had  good luck with this recipe  prepared either way. It turned out  good.

There is no possibility the you can make the "best spanish rice" using a jar of store bought salsa. Firstly, it will taste like the salsa, not spanish rice. This is better called rice with salsa. country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe 3  times now, and each time I try something a little different. The first time I made it according to the recipe, but added some extra spices and some grilled chicken to give it some additional flavor.

The second time I made it, I added in peppers, corn, and black beans, and that came out fantastic!

And the third time, I made it with brown rice, which came out good, but not as good as with white rice. It also took more than double the time to absorb the broth mixture.

I highly recommend this recipe, it's super simple, but really delicious, and there's lots of ways you can jazz it up.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have tried a bunch of Spanish Rice recipes, and decided this is my favorite. You can mix it up to suit your taste buds pretty easy. I agree with the other reviewers, sauting the rice is a must. I don't brown mine, but wait until the beads look solid, you can put onion in while doing this step, but definitely not garlic-add that right before you include the liquids. Resist the urge to open the lid during cooking and resting time, you will be rewarded! I have used many different kinds of rice, brown rice will take extra time to cook beyond the package directions, and you should still saute it ?? Happy cooking!

Bernadette Wesolowski

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3912427.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely LOVED this Spanish rice and so did my family!! I would say I'm not TOO savvy in the kitchen but I'm not bad. I usually shy away from making a receipe I've found online for fear of messing it up or having a hard time making it altogether. This was a VERY easy one to follow and will make my spanish rice like this from now on. I followed the receipe as is. I just added a few chopped up red bell peppers. I personally would say use fresh ingredients, like the lime and orange. I think the lime juice would've made it too sour. Also, BROWN THE RICE FIRST! Usually when I make normal white rice the rice is more stickier and not as "fluffy". Well I feel spanish rice is supposed to made a littler fluffier. Browning the rice made my rice not sticky and it came out perfect! It doesn't take long and definitely worth it! Just make sure not to over brown them.  If you're looking for an easy, flavorful Spanish rice look no further!! You've found it!
Review:

5

text:
I could write all day and not say enough about this awesome recipe.  It's perfectly easy, and so simple with little prep time. 
 After all's in the pot and simmering I set the timer and always have perfectly moist Spanish rice to fluff and perfectly seasoned each time.  Sure wish I'd had this recipe sooner.  I tried others and weren't so pleased, they'd either be too soft and mushy, and the taste was off.  I use organic chicken broth and when I use brown rice I add a little more broth and simmer 15 minutes longer.

text:
I've been looking for a good, easy spanish rice recipe. This was delicious, Even my husband (from Texas) loved it. I followed the recipe completely and used "mild" pace picante sauce.  Also, follow the advice of the reviewer, Karen Hintz. I covered the pot with tin foil, and did not peak for the 20 minutes while it simmered and then let it sit for 5 minutes before taking of the foil. It was perfect and had great flavor.

text:
Easy to make.  Growing up in Asia we always wash the rice before we cook it.  Not because of reasons like so it won’t be starchy blah blah but because sometimes these rice have bugs that grow in it.  Not that these bugs are toxic but you are better taking them off.  Besides these rice are harvested using  either human hands or machine you are better off cleaning them first.   Lots of potential of  this dish and you can certainly season it the way you like it.   Just buy the right variety of rice.

text:
Very good.  We made it as listed, except tossed in some fresh oregano because we had it on hand.  I like the short cut that the salsa provided.  A lot of flavor added in one fell swoop.

Only issue was the cooking time.  Our simmer was a bit low, and we had to turn it up a bit for another 10 minutes to get the liquid to absorb.  Next time will probably use standard rice technique, bring to boil, reduce to simmer for 20 minutes.

text:
This was sooooooo good! I took some of the ideas in reviews and made the best rice dish I've ever had. I cut the recipe in half since there were only 2 of us. We both had seconds and there are still leftovers. I used about a 1/3 cup of chopped onion and 1/3 cup of chopped red pepper. I added a little extra broth since I added more veggies. I used our favorite salsa, Frog Ranch, and added nearly a cup. Sauteing  the rice is a must, and don't peak while it's cooking.

Display Name:
Jahred Tahara (Helleri)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I feel I can only give four stars because I was unable to follow the full recipe exactly do to lack of ingredients and current inability to go and get the proper in ingredients (that is to say that I am unable to see the full effect of following the recipe exactly). But the proportions and steps remain roughly the same and I got excellent results. I did make some substitutions and additions out of necessity (this may be useful to those who must also make changes on the fly):


Unsalted Clarified Butter (a tablespoon more than the required amount of oil).
El Pato sauce instead of chunky salsa.
About a tablespoon more of chopped onion and added a table spoon of fresh copped garlic (to make up for using a thinner sauce).

Given my changing things around a little bit I found that I needed to add 1 cup water towards what should have been the burner-off point and continue to simmer for 8 more minutes to fully cook all grains of rice.  Of course my heat may have been a tad too high. And I was cooking with cast iron. Which could have been a larger contributor to needing additional cook time and water.

Overall I feel it was the simplicity and conciseness of the recipe that allowed me to prevail despite not having everything I needed. The good base let me make small adjustments on the fly.

Very good! I had to make one change, though. I didn't have any chicken broth, so I used beef. Tasted great!

I followed the advice to bring the liquid to a full boil before lowering the heat and letting it simmer. 20 minutes on the flame, five off, and it was as nice and fluffy as you'd get at a restaurant. 

The only thing I'd do differently next time is cut the recipe in half. It makes way too much for two people. LOL. Way too much.

I followed the recipe, frying the onion and rice in a cast iron pan. Then added the wet bits and baked loosely covered in the oven for 20 minutes at 400 degrees F. Pulled out, Stirred a bit and let rest to get just a bit dryer. Turned out pretty close to restaurant style!  Cast iron is the answer to awesome cooking.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base for the recipe.  However, for one, I noted there weren't any spices listed to add to it to "give it a kick."  And the second thing I noted was it called for too much rice for the liquid listed.  I cut it down to just 1 cup of rice.  Also, while toasting the rice, I added 2 1/2 teaspoons of chili powder, 1 teaspoon of granulated garlic and 1 1/2 teaspoons of cumin.   I make my own homemade salsa, so I used that instead of store bought.  This did the trick!  And for some texture and a little "paella" feel, I added 1 1/4 cups of frozen, precooked shrimp.  Came out fabulous and my husband loved it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe, simple as it is, is GREAT!   I LOVE that, including oil, this recipe only uses 5 ingredients and it tastes GREAT!  Not too spicy, so totally kid friendly, but if you like a bit more kick to it, you can add in some cayenne pepper, hot sauce, etc.  according to your tastes!  
I totally agree with Karen Hintz that you MUST sauté the rice before adding the liquids in.  It just has to be done.  Believe me, if you try it, you will definitely notice the difference.   Doing so, this way, will ensure that your rice comes out PERFECT, not gummy like sometimes happens with rice.

text:
it was very good and cheep to make, but the recipe did not say to cook the rice first which I thought was a little odd. so I made it without cooking the rice first and it came out a little crunchier than I would have liked. I do not know if using brown rice contributed to this at all but I would recommend at least partially cooking the rice before preparing this dish as specified. Other than that it turned out quite good, and using spicy salsa gave it an extra kick.

Texture was beautiful, but like a previous reviewer stated, it was really lacking in flavour. The salsa flavours just evaporate! With some ground sea salt, ground black pepper and tabasco sauce, it was gorgeous! Great texture though. I thoroughly recommend cooking the rice gently in oil first, this is how I cook my pilau rice. It gives perfect rice every time. Individual grains, not all stuck together in a soggy mess!

text:
This recipe is bland and not according to the true Spanish style of cooking.  Please add the following to make it proper Spanish Rice.
1 x Pinch of Salt and Pepper
1 x 1/4 Teaspoon of Paprika
1x 1/2 Teaspoon of Garlic Salt or fresh garlic
1 x 1/4 Teaspoon of Cumin
1 x 1/2 Teaspoon of chilli flakes
1 x Red Pepper

text:
I used Medium Pace Salsa, and it wasn't chunky. I didn't think it'd be spicy enough so I added chili flakes to the browning process of the rice. I was right and the flakes were a wonderful touch. I also sauteed some garlic with the onions just for fun, don't know if it made any significant difference though :p. I didn't have broth on hand so I used some bouillon to make some artificial broth which worked perfectly. I also reduced the serving size to three servings and it took about five minutes extra to cook through to the perfect consistency. I loved the end result!! would make again

text:
Easy and fantastic! I used Minute Rice (white), and had no chicken broth so used beef broth. Used Pace mild chunky salsa. Barely sauteed the rice to translucence in the fresh chopped onions and oil. I was worried about over-cooking the rice, but I trusted the recipe and cooked it for the 20 minutes. It was just right and was almost too easy. My husband absolutely loved this. Definitely making it again!

text:
Wonderful flavor! I've made this twice now and both times I cooked it differently. The first time I cooked the rice as the recipe indicated and it was wonderful. The next time I steamed the rice in vegetable broth then stirred in the other ingredients because I read the recipe ingredients but forgot to read the directions so ended up using no oil. You know what? Just as good! So I guess do what you want and it turns out great.

text:
I didn't have any salsa so I used enchileda sauce and some stewed tomato and it worked very well. After it was done I put in a baking pan and then mixed in a pound of cooked hamburger some quartered black olives and Mexican blend cheese on top and put in oven at 350° until cheese was good and melted and had a meal done in no time. I've made this dish before but this rice was the best and easiest I'm using this recipe from now on. And will use the salsa like it calls for. My family really enjoyed it.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1433091.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe it helped me in finding my grove with what works best for my family. I have how ever tweeted the recipe a bit. I add 1 tsp garlic salt, 1/2 and a smiggen over of ground comino because I love the taste and smell it reminds me of being a young girl and being at my grandmothers home when she would cook family meals. 

You must sauté the rice just till it gets a little color it helps it to cook in this recipe. I add fresh tomatoes for taste/ look with the onions and about 1/3 of a can tomato sause for flavor and look because this is what helps to color the rice just the way the salsa does. Depending on who I'm feeding depends on if I do or don't add the salsa. 

I also add a few other seasonings but very lightly: garlic powder, onion powder, seasonal salt (low salt) and pepper. Before putting the lid on for the summer I taste the broth just a few drops in the palm or a spoon how ever you prefer to see how it tastes. This isn't a dish that you can check on half way through lifting the lid ruins it and to much water makes it sticky or soggy. Boy have a learned over the years. I honestly believe that making the chicken broth before hand (bouillon cubes and water, is how I do it) makes a world of difference in this rather then how my mom throws in the water and the cubes into the pot before putting on the lid. 

I've taken this for potluck parties, giving it to friends that I know love the it but aren't able to or can't make it for them selves and serve it to my fa

text:
I lived in south Texas more than half of my life, and this recipe measures up to authentic TexMex Spanish Rice in flavor and texture after I made the following adjustments for my preference: 1/4 - 1/3 c. onion rather than 2 T, plus 2 cloves of crushed fresh garlic, and 1/4 t. ground cumin added while sauteing the rice. At the very end, I moved the pan off the hot burner and let everything sit covered for 5 minutes to finish absorbing any moisture before fluffing the rice.

text:
I love this recipe. So easy! When I make it I make my own broth using 2 soft chicken bouillon cubes (Knorr) and I add a tablespoon or 2 of powdered beef bouillon too. Gives it a very rich flavor. I also add a can of beans (red, black, or kidney beans). For the Salsa, any medium will do just fine, but the Aldi brand organic seems to taste the best to me. I don't add onions either. I don't open the lid at all during cooking. That seems to make sure it cooks just right. I could eat this all the time.

text:
I made this recipe in my instant pot electric pressure cooker, so after sautéing the onions and rice, I added the remaining ingredient and set the cooker to low pressure for 10 minutes followed by a slow release.  I used uncle bens parboiled rice, and a medium salsa. Came out great, will definitely make again!

text:
I made this last night and it was a hit with our whole family. I will definitely make it again.

Based on other reviews, I used more onion and added some cumin. I used a small diced onion, and added about 1/2 tsp. of cumin. I also didn’t “peek” into the pot during the cooking time (some other reviewers suggested that is the key to getting the rice fully cooked in the assigned cooking time. It worked for me.)

text:
I make this rice all the time.  It's yummy and easy.  Especially with the changes I made.  I just use 2 TB dehydrated minced onion instead of fresh, I use brown rice instead of white, up the broth by a quarter cup and finally I just add a 10 oz can of rotel and put it all in my rice cooker and push the button!

text:
I found that 2 cups of Chicken Broth made my rice very "wet" more like porridge. I guess it's because I used Asian Jasmine Rice which tends to be more moist than other rice grains. To fix the issue I used 1.5 Cups of Chicken Broth and it came out PERFECT! Nice and moist, but not too much.

text:
This recipe truly is the best homemade Spanish rice I've had. It is restaurant quality! I have even "healthified" this recipe a bit for those watching calories. Used riced cauliflower, omitted chicken broth, reduced oil to 1 &1/2 tbsp, added spices to make up for broth (onion/garlic powder, oregano, black pepper), and fried it all up. Obviously the texture is different, but the taste is still amazing!

text:
This was pretty good. We live overseas where good Mexican/Spanish food is VERY difficult to come by, so we have to make our own. I did fry my rice, which made the cooking time much longer. I only cooked 1 cup of rice, and used 2 1/4 cups water (per the rice directions), but it took about 30-40 minutes for the rice to soak up the water. Even then the rice was pretty firm - almost crunchy. Next time I think I won't fry my rice for more than about a minute.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never felt the need to review a recipe but I am always thankful for the people that do. I love reading the honest opinions and using everyones tips to tweak a recipe for the better. I just finished making this recipe for the first time and it tastes so incredible I had to let everyone know! I scaled it back a bit to serve fewer people. Here are my slight variations: equal parts (1 cup) salsa, chicken broth and rice. I chose to use olive oil but also added a Tbsp of butter for a slight butter flavor. I also chose to use green onions vs. white or yellow and I was very generous with the amount (approx. 3/4c or so). I think the most important tip is to use a well made salsa. I used leftover salsa from my local Mexican restaurant so naturally it was restaurant style vs. chunky but it didn't matter because the taste is wonderful. Thank you for this fantastic recipe.

jstorment
isPro:

madeRecipesCount:
27
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/468924.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried about 15 or 20 different Spanish rice recipes over the years as its one of my favorite sides to accompany Mexican and Spanish cuisine.  Some have been better than others, but nearly all have fallen short.  I didn't think this one would be any good because there are so few ingredients, but decided to try it since I was cooking for a picky eater who likes food with fewer, simpler ingredients.  Success!!!  I will never, ever use another recipe again.  I've made it several times since and it has never let me down.  I cook from scratch, however because of food allergies in my household, so instead of using store bought salsa, I mix a can of organic tomatoes (or a few fresh that are quartered), a quarter cup of loosely chopped onion, with a good bunch of chopped cilantro, salt, garlic clove, a few slices of pickled jalepeno, and some pickled jalepeno juice, pulse a few times in a food processor, and use that, with the extra saved for the main meal.  I usually add a bit of cumin to the rice and some fresh chopped cilantro after its cooked.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, this recipe is so similiar to a recipe that my family has been using for several generations. We use homemade salsa, but store bought salsa works well too. The only thing missing is a tsp of mexican oregano added to the rice while it's browning. That little step adds so much flavor to the rice. What i like about this recipe is the ratio of salsa and chicken broth to rice is perfect. The rice isn't mushy or undercooked. In the past I've had to press the liquid from the salsa and add that to the broth, then add the pressed salsa to the rice and saute for a min or two before adding the liquid. I agree that the rice should be browned, it gives the rice a more robust flavor. I also like to add diced green chiles to mine for a little more kick. All in all this is a very good recipe and i think i will follow your ratio instead of eyeing it like i've been doing (sorry abuela)thanks for a quick and easy recipe!!

text:
The recipe as-is is only worth about two stars but the idea was a great starter and quick.  I used an entire chopped onion which I browned, then added 1 tsp minced garlic and cooked it for 30 seconds before adding the rice.  I did brown the rice before adding the liquid but I won't do that next time as I didn't appreciate the bite.  I used the Safeway Deli salsa which is excellent, added 1 small can of diced green chiles, 1 tsp ground cumin, salt, pepper and also used 3 cans of low- sodium chicken broth (14.05 oz) as even for basic rice the recipe is 1:2 (rice to water.)  This is a far better alternative than boxed Spanish rice and nearly as fast, so thanks.

text:
Before finding this recipe I experimented for years trying to recreate that Mexican restaurant-style rice. This one comes closer than anything else I have tried, and I have since made it no less than a dozen times. I typically use brown rice, and add a handful of frozen, diced carrots and peas when I add the broth for color. Though I had never bought Pace picante sauce for my own consumption before, I tried it based on the other reviews and really liked it. Now I buy the big jugs of it at the warehouse store just for this dish. I always make a double batch and freeze half.

country:
None
text:
This is a delicious quick recipe. I used a time-saver to speed up the recipe. 

I cook my rice in a rice cooker in the morning; this allows me to have the rice ready to cook with later in the day. When I start the recipe in the evening, I first sauté the onions, then add the cooked rice followed by the salsa. Finally, I add one cup of vegetarian broth to the rice and allow it to simmer to remove excess water.

It's delish and all that much quicker ;)

Great recipe, only substituted a can of diced tomatoes for the chunky salsa, I didn't have any.  Made a large quantity of 4 cups.  I used 2 1/2 cups of liquid per cup of rice, covered it and let it come to a hard boil, then turned off the heat and let it continue to cook for 25 minutes, it was perfect!  Just don't be tempted to uncover during the last 25 minutes, it'll be perfect.

None
text:
I should have read more of the reviews before making this. I didn't use 1 cup of rice - instead using the 1.5 cups the recipe calls for - and my rice was still crunchy after the specified cooking time. I let it steam for an additional 5 minutes here-and-there, checking it each time the timer went off, until it had steamed for an additional 20 minutes, but it still had some crunchy bits. By this time the rest of my meal was cold so I had to give up on the rice. Despite not being done, I liked the flavor. I'd make this again, but use the correct rice-to-water ratio.

So for years I've been using a different spanish rice recipe that I found on this site - I'm done with that one now.  THIS is how spanish rice is supposed to taste!!  And it's so much easier to make!  I don't recommend boiling the rice or doing this in the microwave....spanish  rice isn't supposed to be mushy.  Totally worth sauteeing it in a pan first.  YUM! photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this rice, but with a few key modifications.  First, after adding in the liquids, I allowed it to come to a full boil for about 2 minutes before allowing it to simmer.  Secondly, having made this before and finding it to be a bit bland (and simmering it for nearly an hour because I followed the directions exactly, without allowing it to boil first), I went ahead and added salt, garlic powder and onion powder.  I found that it was far more flavorful this time around.   As with any Spanish rice recipe, sautéing the rice is a critical step that you will pay for in flavor and texture if you skip.

text:
This is similar to the recipe I've used for years. I follow the recipe except add more onion (around a half cup). I add a can of Rotele. This adds extra liquid and an added depth to the taste. I try to keep a bag of either chopped or sliced mixed peppers and onions in the freezer. I often use them when I don't want to bother with chopping up an onion. I save the salsa for after the rice is done. We mix in a bunch of shredded cheese, top with sour cream and salsa, leftover taco meat is also a great addition.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This spanish rice is straight up comfort food!  It is super easy to make, DELICIOUS, and it makes great leftovers, so you can enjoy it for days.  I originally made it to accompany chicken fajitas, though it is great on it's own (or mixed with a little sour cream and cheddar cheese), on a taco salad, or in burritos.  My husband, who is the pickiest eater I know, LOVES it.  I make it several times a month and it comes out perfectly every time.  I would make it more often, but I fear I might eat the whole batch and supersize myself!  I like to sneak extra veggies into everything I make, so with this I use a whole onion and at least one bell pepper.  Other things I will likely try in the future include corn, celery, carrots, or peas.  I might even get away with some chopped up cauliflower.  I also like the idea of using brown rice to "healthy it up" a little bit.  We'll see if my hubbie even notices...  Enjoy :)

text:
Better than any spanish rice I have ever had. This has become a family staple and a requirement any time we have tacos, taco salad, burritos, fajitas, etc... My oldest daughter loves it and she doesn't even like rice. I make it per the recipe except I use chicken bouillon cubes(2) instead of chicken broth as I usually don't have chicken broth on hand. I also use 3 cups of water with the bouillon cubes as I found I was always adding water as it cooked down too fast. Sometimes we add leftover chicken to it to make it a meal all by itself. My family would give this 10 stars if they could.

My youngest daughter really likes red rice from Rubios so I endeavored to make it at home using my rice cooker.  This recipe was her favorite of the three that I tried.  I used the saute setting on my rice cooker to cook the onion, then added the rice, letting it brown just a bit.  I substituted Rotel tomatoes & chilis for the salsa and added 1/2 t. of cumin.  I turned the rice cooker to white rice and let it cook as I would any white rice.  It turned out perfect!

text:
This is really good rice - and I don't even like rice!  My only mistake was keeping the temperature too high after I added the broth and salsa - it looked like way too much liquid to be absorbed when I first added it, so if it looks like way too much liquid to you, still lower the temperature - it will absorb and turn out great.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/906934.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use a similar recipe.  The key ingredient is using a salsa that you already know you like.  I also add a half teaspoon of cumin and a half teaspoon of salt if I have used the liquid from cooking chicken instead of packaged broth.  Using chicken broth is best but it turns out very well even if you use only plain water.  I heat the liquid, salsa and seasonings while I'm browning the rice, then add the rice to the simmering liquid, cover, reduce heat and cook for 20 minutes.

I have made this many times now. Sometimes with quick brown and others with white. It always turns out perfect. I think people that didn't care for it used a salsa that was not good to start with...the rice can only be as good as the salsa. I use Jack's Cantina Style. There is no added sugar and only natural ingredients and the taste is amazing on it's own.

text:
Pleasantly surprised!  Was afraid it would be to bland due to the lack of ingredients.  However, that was not the case.  It had wonderful flavor for such a simple recipe.  After browning the rice I threw everything in a rice cooker minus a bit of the liquid and added a pinch of chili powder.  In no time we had perfect rice.  Unlike many other rices, this one tasted just as good reheated as it did fresh.

Display Name:
Karla Blakely
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1679761.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this almost exactly as written and  it is amazing! It is almost as good as the rice a Hispanic family I know makes from scratch and not nearly as complex.

My rice did get a little dried out and browned on the bottom but I used a non-stick pan and I stirred it as soon as the 20 minutes were up and it's just fine...it might have cooked a little quick because I might have had the heat up too high so that is my fault and not the recipes.

I didn't use onion, because I didn't have any, so I used a bell pepper instead.  I didn't use a chunky salsa I just used Wal-Mart salsa and added a little cumin, chili powder and onion powder to it because I can't make Spanish Rice without adding in some cumin.

Display Name:
