photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/826289.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had a hankering for Spanish rice, and decided to give this a go. It is the best I have ever had in recent memory! It was no harder than preparing it from a package (= ridiculously easy), and had LOTS more flavor than I ever remember the boxed stuff having. It will end up highlighting the flavors of whatever salsa you use, so make sure you like the salsa you plan to cook this with. I used jasmine rice, and onion powder rather than cutting up an onion. I used a tomato based salsa with peach and mango, which made it slightly sweet and that may sound odd, but it worked well with the jasmine rice, and provided contrast to the creamy refried beans and spicy chicken tacos I ate it with. I usually skip the Spanish rice with Mexican-style meals, but this was so good I am considering making it regularly with Mexican food. Thank you for the recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quick & easy.
I must disagree with the reviewer who suggest covering this tightly, though!
Why is "Spanish rice" called "Spanish"?
It's basically a quick, cheap version of paella.
Ever seen a paella chef cover his paella pan with aluminum foil?
Open cooking works great, and it also gives it that tasty bottom "crust"!
Enjoy!

text:
By far the best spanish rice I have ever made! I made this a couple nights ago with slow cooker carnitas also from this site. Also made the mexican corn with it. Best meal I have made in a long time! I barely changed anything. Was good as is. I used corn and black bean salsa, since that was all I had on hand. The only change I would make next time would be to add an extra 1/2 cup of broth. Was just a tad bit too dry.
Overall... really easy, and flavorful. I will be making this again this weekend when we have company over

If you mess up either of those your rice will have problems.

region:

country:
None
text:
Perfect title because this IS the best spanish rice I've ever had, yet so simple to make and such basic ingredients!  I had already made all the other ingredients for my burrito (beans, guacamole, etc), except for the rice. I was going to use my Rice-a-Roni, but found my last box to be infested with bugs. So that's when I searched here to make it from scratch and very glad I chose this one. I'll never go back to boxed Spanish Rice again! 
For the broth, I made it with a seasoning pack from the Ramen noodles (I always have a lot leftover since I don't use the whole pack when making Ramen noodles). I also made my own salsa (tomatoes, peppers, onions, cilantro, salt/pepper, lemon juice, olive oil). I'd say that the homemade salsa is a key ingredient.  I made this rice the 2nd time with the canned salsa, and wasn't crazy about.

Fantastic recipe! Very easy with delicious results. text:
Excellent after I changed the cooking method. I made it the first time according to dirctions and the rice was still crunchy after 45 min.  Since then I have made it this way: 1 cup salsa (thinner=better), 2 cups chicken broth, 1 1/2 cup white rice brought to a boil in a saucepan, reduce heat to low, cover and simmer 20 min. Comes out perfect every time!

text:
I didn't have any onion in the house so I used a minced clove of garlic that I browned in the oil (key is to let the garlic heat with the oil, always start with a cold pan).  Then I used a wild rice combination (Royal Blend, Rice Blend) that has Texmati white, brown, wild, and red.  It was very colorful and not bland at all!  Also used a mexican brand of medium salsa that was NOT chunky.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hello all. I made this with all brown rice, and as one reader said, the normal distinctive taste of the brown rice was completely covered which was great.  I doubled the onions, used vegetable broth instead of chicken, and used only 3/4 cup of salsa because it was a spicy salsa, and I didn't want it to get too hot.  I cooked it for the recommended 20 minutes, and then left it on the turned off warm burner for another 7.  I added a little parmesan cheese on top as well. This was delicious!! The flavouring was unbelievable.  It was pretty spicy, so I will try it next time with normal salsa to see the difference, but I will definitely be making it this way again!!! So easy, and so yummy!

text:
Delicious and authentic! I added about 3 TBSP chopped green bell pepper with the onion, sauteed it together in the oil, added the rice (jasmine) and sauteed for about 3-4 minutes before added 2 minced cloves of garlic, sauteed another 1-2 minutes then added the broth and salsa. Excellent texture. This will be made again! Really good with Mexican Chicken I from this site.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
They're right about browning the rice before cooking... it really makes a delicious flavor.  I have made this recipe several times and always do it a bit differently.  My favorite is to skip the salsa and instead start the whole thing out by throwing a bunch of over-ripe fresh tomatoes and other random veggies into some broth and cooking till they get soft, then putting in the rice.  You end up with nice big veggie pieces in the rice that way and it only takes an extra 5 mins or so.

country:
None
text:
This is THE best, most authentic (from my experiences) spanish rice I have ever had! I did deviate a bit, because I always fail to measure and use my eye instead... I was heavy on olive oil, likely, and used scallion instead of onion. I used Pace Chunky medium salsa, and was a tad light on the rice, maybe. DO NOT UNCOVER the rice!!!!! You must let it do its thing. You also MUST saute, though I did it gradually and never to browning. That seems to give it that extra texture that I love so much. GReat recipe!!! Thank you ilovetocook!

This rice is as easy as it looks, and is very tasty when the recipe is followed exactly. It is super easy to add cooked chicken or pork to for a meal-in-a-pot type recipe. text:
I made this recipe as directed, but coming up on only 3 minutes left, there was a problem... not enough liquid.  I added another cup of chicken broth, but in the end it really needed a total of 3 1/4-3 1/2 C broth.  Also, the time was WAY underestimated.  It took 40 minutes.  Also, must be careful when "browing" the rice to not burn the onions.  Otherwise, very close to restaurant-style.

userID:
2909593
Display Name:
Super*Sweet<3
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, first of all I am not hispanic, but I had a first Generation Mexican American ex-sis-in-law that made some great spanish rice!  I personally loved this recipe and compared to hers, well I think I found a rice recipe that I will stick with!  I only had salsa to start with and while I was skeptical of it coming out tasting like Pace chunky Salsa, surprisingly it didn't but I could tell that it helped flavor the rice, as well as, the 2 cups of hot water with a Knorrs Bouillon Cube.  I put the water and the Cube in the Microwave while I was sauting my onions and garlic.  I added more onions than called for and garlic and sprinkled them with cumin.  I then added the rice and sauteed the combo and sprinkled more cumin.  My ex-sis-in-law always sauteed her onions and rice with cumin, as do most hispanic people!  It adds something more authentic to this recipe.  So, if you must know Sauting the rice for like a quick 2 minutes will do you don't really want to brown them like dark brown you want to simply heat them to a a very light golden color and with all that rice you will more than likely not be able to get all of them even if you keep stirring for the two minutes.  Doing this will make the rice a tiny bit more stiff than steamed rice, but it shouldn't be hard.  If it comes out chewy and hard than you sauteed the rice way too long!!!  I stuck with the amounts of water and salsa suggested put it on a very low heat and cooked it for 20 minutes.  The rice didn't stick and while i
Review:
Rating:
5

This is the recipe to use if you want an authentic flavorful Spanish rice recipe.  So easy and delicious.  I think the brand of salsa you use can make a difference, although one time I used the generic store brand - because it was the cheapest in a high priced market - and it came out just as good! .

text:
My fiance whom is Cuban loves rice, but I get tired of eating the same three different rices I make. I thought this would be a change and had high hopes. Was I wrong! My own home made rice is way better! I followed the recipe and felt that two cups of broth was not enough. So I added a half cup of water, and salt to taste. The dish I felt had no flavor, the Picante sauce over powered the rice. I will use this recipe again, but I will add chicken bullion to give it flavor. Gave four stars, because fiance loved it.
